key_insight: The paper introduces neural stochastic differential equations that learn state-dependent drift and diffusion to generatively model single-cell dynamics, producing more accurate, realistic trajectories than prior approaches. This enables simulation and counterfactual perturbation studies of development and disease.
problem_solved: Accurately modeling continuous-time, stochastic cell state dynamics from noisy single-cell data and enabling realistic simulation and perturbation analysis.
method: Use neural stochastic differential equations (neural SDEs) to parameterize state-dependent drift and diffusion terms with neural networks.
Train a generative continuous-time model to reconstruct observed cell trajectories and sample realistic future/latent paths with uncertainty.
Use the learned model to run in silico perturbations and compare predicted developmental or disease outcomes.
impact: Provides a scalable, principled framework for modeling complex stochastic dynamics in biology, advancing continuous-time generative modeling techniques. Useful to ML practitioners working on time-series, generative models, and causal/perturbation simulation across domains.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram: neural network → learned drift & diffusion → stochastic trajectory sampler (neural SDE pipeline).
Trajectory plots: observed single-cell snapshots vs. generated continuous trajectories with uncertainty bands.
Performance comparison: bar/line chart showing accuracy/likelihood against baseline models.
Perturbation schematic: before/after simulated perturbation trajectories highlighting predicted shifts in cell fate.
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
